utterances: Hello, Michele.
I understand that you have 12 employees right now, if this bill passes, do you plan to hire any more?
No, we don't.
At the current state, construction is at a standstill and our business is closely related to the construction industry.
We have to see growth in the industry before we add any more bodies into our system.
Help us understand just how hard the housing market has been hit there in Phoenix.
Specifically, I can tell you that our revenue numbers are roughly a third of where they were two years ago.
Construction in the Phoenix area has virtually come to a standstill.
The amount of inventory that is still on the market needs to be dissipated.
And most of the banks and financial institutions are hesitant or just are not loaning any money to developers to start any new housing programs.
Is there anything the federal government could do that would convince you to hire new employees?
Yeah, the key thing that the federal government can do to convince us to hire is to get the construction industry growing.
In order for them to get the construction industry growing they have to really light the economy on fire.
And they have to free up the financial institutions to be able to start loaning to people who want to start building houses.
Well Mr. Hann, all the best to you.
Thank you very much for taking time to talk to us.
Fear and dread.
We all have glitches somewhere in our instructions books that place us at risk for something.
The opportunity to discover those and to individualize our individual plans of prevention is one of the major hopes that we have for reducing our health care costs and keeping people healthy.
Even the health insurance industry has signed onto the importance of genetic privacy.
In theory, some business groups, however, worry that the bill could invite frivolous lawsuits.
And there are concerns about the language of the bill.
Janet Trautwein is with the National Association of Health Underwriters.
She worries how the term genetic information is defined.
You know, now, that the definition is so broad you could bring in something like cholesterol screening and potentially define that as a genetic test.
Right now, health insurers are allowed to base the premiums they charge for individual policies on a person's medical history.
Trautwein says if the new law walls off too much of that information, it could do more harm than good.
If we make the definition too broad so that we can ask fewer and fewer questions, then underwriters will have to be more and more conservative in their rates.
The costs will go up, and I'm very afraid that people will be priced out of coverage.
But with Democrats back in charge in the House, those objections are carrying less weight.
That's a relief to the bill's longtime sponsor, New York Democratic congresswoman and microbiologist Louise Slaughter.
There needs to be some privacy, and most Americans want that.
I think it will pass rather handsomely, and the nicest thing is the president will sign it.
He's already said that.
The full House and Senate are expected to vote on the bill in the next few weeks.
Julie Rovner, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Israeli forces have rolled into the southern Gaza Strip and have launched air strikes on at least two bridges as Israel presses for the release of a captured Israeli soldier.
Israeli helicopters also attacked a Palestinian power plant this evening, causing a power outage across Gaza City.
Meantime today, two rival Palestinian factions say they've actually agreed on a common political program, at least on paper.
Fatah and Hamas say the document was drafted by prisoners in Israeli jails.
It aims to end violence that has claimed dozens of lives in the past few months and paves the way for a possible power sharing arrangement.
But not all in Hamas have signed off, suggesting deep internal divisions within Hamas.
From Gaza, NPR's Eric Westervelt reports.
The so-called prisoners' document calls for the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel within borders that existed before the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
It also asserts the right of return of Palestinian refugees to land which is now part of Israel proper.
But leaders on the ground in Gaza have less lofty immediate goals, end the running battles between Fatah and Hamas gunmen on Gaza streets.
Samir Mushuloui(ph) a Fatah leader here was a chief negotiator with Hamas.
(Through translator) So we hope that this document will provide the base for an end of all kind of tension and internal conflict.
Mushuloui, guarded by ten heavily armed young militants, says he hopes the agreement leads to national unity government, genuine power sharing and an easing of crippling international sanctions.
But neither side appears convinced that it will.
Asked if the agreement will end inter-Palestinian fighting, Hamas leader Khalid Abu Leila says, to be honest, I don't think it will at all.
Fatah officials say that Hamas signing off on the document inches the militant Islamists towards recognizing the Jewish state's right to exist.
Abu Leila says, that's nonsense.
(Through translator) Our principles and statements are we will never recognize Israel.
In the complex turbulent chess match of current Palestinian politics, many say today's agreement simply highlights the growing splits within Hamas.
A more radical exile leadership based in Syria and led by Khalid Mishal today said there is no deal yet.
Musah Abu Marzuk, a top Hamas official, told reporters in Damascus, we hope within the next few days we'll reach an agreement on a joint agenda, but not today.
Many analysts believe Khalid Mishal approved the deadly weekend attack on an Israeli border post.
They say it was aimed in part at sabotaging any Hamas/Fatah agreement that might lead to a resumption of peace talks with Israel.
Analyst Jihad Hamed heads the independent Center for Strategic Studies in Gaza.
He says this weekend's attack showed the exiled leadership flexing its muscle and commitment to a militarist program.

It seems to me that this is part of their agenda to get out from the whole political and dispute within the Palestinian society to go for a military operation to make it clear to all players in this conflict that outside of (unintelligible) the decision maker, when it comes to the critical issues.
Nadil Abu Rudeina, a Fatah lawmaker, says the splits within Hamas make it hard at times to tell just who is in charge of the group.
That could be one of the obstacles or that we are all facing, us and the Israelis and the world.
Hamas's January election win catapulted a militant group that uses terrorist tactics, what Hamas calls resistance to the political leadership of the Palestinian authority.
That quick rise, analysts say, was bound to create splits.

Kisah Abdul Kareem, an independent lawmaker with ties to Fatah, says Hamas leaders were under intense pressure from their militant base to respond to the recent civilian deaths from Israeli air strikes.
Ever since their success in the elections, they call for social strength for the first time in history, so there is this internal tension.
We wanted to send Carl out the way he wants by simply doing a good radio show.
We go next to Simone Wilker in Paramus, New Jersey.
She and husband own AlphaGraphics, a printing and marketing shop.
Ms. Wilker, you have five employees, is that correct?
(Owner, AlphaGraphics) That's absolutely correct.
Are you planning on making any new hires?
Well, I would love to be able to hire a new salesperson because I think it would be great to increase our sales and our revenues.
So, that I definitely have in my mind.
I'll take that as a maybe.
I guess it depends on the financial ramifications of hiring someone new at this point in time.
Now if you hired someone, you would potentially be exempt from the 6.2 percent social security payroll tax through the month of December - that make a difference at all to you?
Oh, yeah, that would be nice.
I mean every penny counts.
That's the only way I can explain it.
Every single penny counts.
We're watching everything that we purchase.

And we're watching our costs and paring everything down to the bone and that's why I'm really considering hiring someone new because if we could now increase our revenues and our sales, it would make a big difference to us.

Now as you know the debate here in Washington as to whether this bill would actually do enough to create jobs - you're the second small business owner we talked to, the first said he's not going to hire someone.
You're saying well, I might do it but I'm not so sure.
What would the government have to do to move you definitively and very quickly to yes, I'm going to hire someone?
I guess it would be to increase the amount that they're willing to give you as an incentive.
I mean I would love to see $5,000 or $10,000.
And I would say that having someone on the rolls as an unemployed individual is costing the government a bundle at this point in time.
And so anything that could help them in hiring new people and getting them off the unemployment rolls would be an incentive for the government to offer me more money.
So in my dreams, they'd be offering the $5,000 or $10,000 to hire someone.
But I don't think that realistic.
So, I would say that a $1,000, plus not having to pay that social security tax for the month of December, would certainly help.
And if I'm already looking to hire somebody, that might be the turning point whether I would hire them or not, and probably I would.
Well, good luck to you, thank you very much for taking time to talk to us.
